Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Echinoderm Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Echinoderms include familiar animals such as starfishes, sea urchins, and a wide array of extinct forms stretching back to the Cambrian Period, circa 500 million years ago. Echinoderms share a common ancestor with backboned animals and thus provide a crucial link to understanding a huge portion of the entire tree of life as well as the history of our species. This project, the Echinoderm Tree of Life Project, will resolve the phylogenetic placement of Echinoderms within the tree of life and clarify important unresolved relationships among major echinoderm lineages using data from genetic sequencing and anatomy.

Echinoderms are fascinating, and their unique features, such as mutable ligaments and novel means of detecting light, have biomedical engineering applications. Because research on such marine animals and their adaptations is naturally attractive to young people, excellent students are expected to be recruited and the importance of science will be communicated to a broad audience. Long-term impacts, embodied by scientific publications, textbooks, anatomical and genomic data, and extensive pages in the Tree of Life and Encyclopedia of Life web projects, will provide resources to researchers and educators. Outreach will include videos and broadcasts about marine exploration and applications of fundamental biological research across the biomedical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Echinoderms include familiar animals such as starfishes, sea urchins, and a wide array of extinct forms stretching back to the Cambrian Period, circa 500 million years ago. Echinoderms share a common ancestor with vertebrate animals and thus provide a crucial link to understanding the entire tree of life as well as the history of our species. The Echinoderm Tree of Life Project clarified important unresolved relationships among the major groups using genetic sequencing, anatomy and phylogenetic analyses.

 

Intellectual Merit:

We have reported on the phylogeny of echinoderms in higher level taxa and species level taxa and extant and living. We used next generation sequencing technologies and phylogenetic analyses to resolve long-standing debates in extant echinoderms. We have been able to place the enigmatic Xyloplax (once thought to be a relict 6th class of echinoderms) among starfishes.

 

We used paleontological data to study the origins and relationships of other taxa within the Echinodermata such as crinoids. This worked allowed us to resolve the phylogenetic position of the Crinoidea within the Echinodermata and to determine phylogenetic relationships among and within the major crinoid clades. Both of these questions were resolved with new data and a new universal homology scheme for echinoderm classes.

 

We produced over 118 products including peer-reviewed papers in journals and books, presentations at conferences and public speaking events, databases, websites and dissertations. Data for morphological analyses is preserved on the online repository https://morphobank.org. More information is posted on the Assembling the Echinoderm Tree of Life Webpage at https://scripps.ucsd.edu/centers/echinotol. 

 

This work has lead to spin off products including the development of new sequence analysis tools and the creation of a large RNAseq database for echinoderms (http://echinodb.uncc.edu/).   In EchinoDB, we have released over 785,000 gene clusters to the public domain and provide an easy to use web-based application to access and work with the data. This product has allowed our work to impact several disciplines beyond our own including neuroscience, developmental biology, gene family studies, and biological materials.  In addition, work on this aspect of the project featured the first studies to utilize tip-dating Bayesian methodologies ?on invertebrate fossils.

 

Broader Impacts:

Computational techniques from this research project will allow for the analysis of large datasets of sequence data (e.g., large scale phylogenetic analyses help us understand the origin and spread of infectious diseases). The use of the database infrastructure will impact many projects (e.g., those that can leverage information from venomous animals toward better therapeutics).

 

In conducting this research we paired students and postdoctoral fellows with more experienced people or people with different skill sets and backgrounds to accomplish cross training.  In addition, students worked with PIs from multiple institutions.  At UNC Charlotte two graduate students, two postdocs and several professionals have been trained. Three graduate students and one postdoc have been trained at OSU. Moreover we increased access to STEM and developed a globally aware workforce through an international research opportunity for undergraduates.

 

We have been mentioned in the media quite often and use these opportunities to express the importance of fundamental research.

 

Below are some examples:

 

"Mention in omics tools" https://omictools.com/search?q=echinodb" Jan 2017

 

“Diving into Marine Genomes and Regenerative Medicine”

http://dhmri.org/news-events/news/2016/599 July 2016

 

"Mention in rna-seq blog" http://www.rna-seqblog.com/tag/echinodb/ Jan 2016

 

”N.C. Science Festival events continue in Charlotte” Charlotte Observer April 14, 2013.

 

”Sea urchins are just one big eye”, Cosmos Magazine (Sydney Australia), July 6, 2011

 

”The Peter Pan of echinoderms revealed” Cosmos Magazine (Sydney Australia) May 6, 2011

 

AAAS radio show ”Science Update”, May 20 and 30, 2011

 

”Scientists find starfish that never grows up” FOX News, May 4, 2011

 

Episode of O-H-I-O ”Uncovering an ancient Tree of Life.” Appeared on the Big Ten Network January 25 and April 19, 2011

 

”Two OSU scientists researching new branch in Tree of Life” The Lantern November 9, 2010

 

”An ocean of questions”. Columbus Dispatch, November 7, 2010.

 

In summary we are grateful for the opportunity to perform this research and contribute a broader understanding of the Tree of Life.
